docs.lead_paragraph: The most intriguing mysteries swirling about Daniel Chavarría are not in his crime novels, but in his life. How does a professor of Latin and Greek classics find fulfillment and fame writing about prostitutes? Why does he live in Cuba, where some people whisper that he arrived 33 years ago on a hijacked flight? And how can he slam back four double shots of smooth, amber rum before noon and not fall flat on his face? Mr. Chavarría says the answers to some of those questions (though perhaps not the last one) are in his books, most notably ''Adios Muchachos'' (Akashic Books, 2001), which won an Edgar Award this year. But his feat of liquid endurance prompts him to reveal one clue.
docs.abstract: Article profiles Cuban crime novelist Daniel Chavarria, whose latest book, Adios Muchachos, won Edgar Award this year; interview; photos; 68-year-old classics professor was born in Uruguay and came to Cuba in 1969 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With prospects for global trade liberalization looking bleak at the moment, the presidents of Brazil and Mexico, Latin America's two biggest economies, signed a bilateral trade deal today instead, opening their markets to each other in 800 industrial and agricultural product categories. Meeting in Brasília, the two presidents -- Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil and Vicente Fox of Mexico -- signed the pact at the start of a tour by President Fox that analysts see as a reorientation of Mexico's interest and attention toward its Latin American neighbors and, in some measure, away from its Nafta partners, the United States and Canada.
docs.abstract: Brazil's Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso and Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox sign bilateral trade deal opening their markets to each other in 800 industrial and agricultural product categories, Brasilia; Brazil and Mexico trade little with each other--$2.6 billion worth of goods and services last year--and both could use boost from expansion of bilateral commerce that new agreement is meant to produce; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Placing responsibility for their countries' woes on the global economy and a rise in protectionism in rich industrialized nations, leaders of South America's main trading bloc, Mercosur, closed ranks behind Argentina, urging international aid for the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Placing responsibility for their countries' woes on the global economy and a rise in protectionism in rich industrialized nations, leaders of South America's main trading bloc, Mercosur, closed ranks behind Argentina, urging international aid for the country, whose economic collapse has sent neighboring markets into a tailspin. But they stopped short of forming a united front to negotiate with international agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, in case the Argentine fallout leaves the region in need of fresh I.M.F. aid. In a statement ending a meeting in Buenos Aires, the presidents of the Mercosur members Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, along with the leaders of two associate countries, Bolivia and Chile, expressed their concern that the current state of the international economic and financial system was preventing sustainable, just and equitable economic development. Tony Smith (NYT)
docs.abstract: Leaders of South America's main trading bloc, Mercosur, meeting, Buenos Aires, urge international aid for Argentina; blames nation's economic woes on global economic conditions and protectionism in rich industrialized nations

docs.lead_paragraph: In matters of culture, Mexico is Latin American. But in matters of money, it is North American. Though most Mexicans rarely say so in public, one of this nation's greatest strengths is its privileged trade status with the United States. The United States economy plays a large role in driving the job market in Mexico, and the dream of advancement comes alive with the hum of the factory floor.
docs.abstract: Some Mexicans disapproved of Pres Vicente Fox's visit to South America this month to increase ties with Brazil and Argentina, fearing that their country will become more likely to contract economic illness afflicting its southern neighbors; Fox, toured region, signed limited trade agreements and promised to integrate Mexico hemispheric free trade organization by 2006, but walked fine line, portraying trip as way for Mexico to show solidarity with its struggling Latin American neighbors while not suggesting to international investors that Mexico is casting its financial lot with them; benefits of partnership with US and Canada have been huge; $254 billion in trade with US last year accounted for about 78 percent of Mexico's total, while $7.3 billion in trade with Canada accounted for additional 2 percent; large part of Mexico's economic stability is result of its anchoring to North American Free Trade agreement; Mexico still feels strong cultural connection to rest of Latin America despite economic benefits of trade with US and Canada; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil's battered currency reached a new low today, as concerns grew about the nation's fragile finances. The government dispatched a mission to Washington today for talks with the International Monetary Fund in an effort to calm market fears. Finance Minister Pedro Malan said a deal with the fund to extend or increase its current $15 billion program that expires in December could be sealed ''in the next days or weeks.''

Buffett is close to a deal to invest as much as $500 million in the Williams Companies, the energy concern, executives close to the talks said. The move would be his second major investment in the debt-ridden energy sector this week and would help keep Williams from filing for bankruptcy protection. The transaction would give Mr. Buffett's MidAmerican Energy Holdings, a unit of Berkshire Hathaway, preferred stock in Williams that would be secured by pipeline assets. docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay said today that it would keep its fragile banking system closed at least through Friday, despite the prospect of fresh aid. Widespread banking restrictions in neighboring Argentina have brought the financial system in Uruguay to the verge of collapse. Uruguay has also been buffeted by turmoil in Brazil, whose currency, the real, fell 5 percent today, to 3.47 to the dollar, its ninth-consecutive low. The currency has lost about 14 percent of its value in just three days.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Israeli Troops Enter Nablus In Retaliation for Bombing A large Israeli Army force swept into the Old City of Nablus to hunt for Palestinian militants in what appeared to be the start of military retaliation for a bombing by Hamas militants on Wednesday at Hebrew University in Jerusalem that killed seven people -- including five Americans -- and wounded more than 80. There were unconfirmed reports of two Palestinians killed in Nablus and a third, a member of Hamas, in a neighboring village. A1 President Bush reacted with outrage to the deaths of the five Americans, telling reporters he was ''furious.'' A1
